This is a '''list of engineering blunders''', i.e., gross errors or mistakes resulting from grave lack of proper consideration, such as stupidity, confusion, carelessness, or culpable ignorance,<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/blunder Blunder], Dictionary.com. ''[[Webster's Revised Unabridged Dictionary]]'' (accessed: February 04, 2009).</ref> which resulted in notable incidents. <!-- Please list here only the incidents which are * notable * have a Wikipedia article or section * described as blunders in multiple valid sources --> *[[Fort Montgomery (Lake Champlain)]] was sometimes referred to as "Fort Blunder", because the first version of the U.S. fort was inadvertently built on the Canadian side of the border. * The [[NASA]] [[Mars Climate Orbiter]], launched in 1998, burned up in the Martian atmosphere. A mixup between metric and [[U.S. customary unit|US Standard]] measurements in the controlling software caused the spacecraft to miss its intended 140–150 km altitude above Mars during orbit insertion, instead entering the Martian atmosphere at about 57 km. * The NASA [[Genesis (spacecraft)|Genesis]] mission was an attempt to sample particles from the solar wind. It successfully collected a sample and returned to Earth. However at the last moment the landing parachute failed to open and the return capsule smashed into the ground at high speed, contaminating the samples. The parachute failure was traced to an [[Genesis (spacecraft)#Mishap_Investigation_Board_(MIB)|accelerometer installed backwards]]. * The Quebec bridge disaster. * [[Tacoma Narrows Bridge (1940)]] * [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill]] caused by a faulty blowout preventer.
==See also== *[[List of disasters]] for aircraft/rail/shipwreck disasters *[[Catastrophic failure#Structural_failure|Catastrophic failure]] Structural failures *[[Space accidents and incidents]] ==External links== *[https://archive.is/20140717230517/http://blunderingboffins.altervista.org/ Drunk photons and the myth of the electromagnetic vorticity]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{italic title}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2015}} '''''Marx in Soho''''' is a 1999 [[one-man play]] written by American historian [[Howard Zinn]], about the life of 19th-century philosopher [[Karl Marx]]. Zinn wrote the play to "show Marx as few people knew him, as a family man, struggling to support his wife and children."<ref>http://bad.eserver.org/reviews/2000/2000-4-25-12.26PM.html</ref> The play is set in the [[New York City]] neighborhood of [[Soho, Manhattan|Soho]], a humorous nod to the [[London]] [[Soho|neighborhood of the same name]] in which Marx spent much of his life.<ref name="foley">F. Kathleen Foley. "[http://articles.latimes.com/2001/may/31/entertainment/ca-4527 Communism Alive and, Well, Pithy With 'Marx']". ''Los Angeles Times''. May 31, 2001.</ref>
''Marx in Soho'' has often been produced. The play depicts Marx resurrected to defend the ideals of [[communism]] from the dehumanized version of it practiced in the former [[Soviet Union]] and to defend humanity from [[capitalism]].<ref name="foley">F. Kathleen Foley. "[http://articles.latimes.com/2001/may/31/entertainment/ca-4527 Communism Alive and, Well, Pithy With 'Marx']". ''Los Angeles Times''. May 31, 2001.</ref>
==Background== [[File:Karl Marx.jpg|thumb|upright|Karl Marx, the protagonist of ''Marx in Soho'', in 1875]]
Zinn writes in his foreword that as early as 17, he had seen dramatic evidence "that the machinery of government was not neutral, that, despite its pretensions, it served the capitalist class.... My Communist friends brought me along with them to a demonstration in [[Times Square]]. Hundreds of people unfurled banners proclaiming opposition to war, opposition to [[Fascism]], and marched along the street. I heard sirens. Mounted police charged the crowd. I was knocked unconscious by a plainclothes policeman. When I came to, as my head was clearing, I could only think one troubling thought: the police, the state, did the bidding of the holders of great wealth. How much freedom of speech and freedom of assembly you had depended on what class you were in."<ref name="sohof">Howard Zinn, [https://books.google.com/books?id=WPKXDJX4Zc4C&lpg=PP1&pg=PR9 ''Marx in Soho: a play on history''], "Foreword", South End Press, 1999. 88 pages. pp. ix-x, xiv. {{ISBN|0-89608-593-7}}</ref>
Zinn continued: "[[Karl Marx|Karl]] and [[Jenny von Westphalen|Jenny Marx]] had moved to London after he was expelled from country after country on the European continent. They lived in the grubby [[Soho]] district, and revolutionaries from all over Europe, arriving in London, trooped in and out of their home. That imagined scene — Marx at home, Marx with his wife, Jenny, with his daughter Eleanor — fascinated me."<ref name="sohof" />
==Reviews== [[File:Howard Zinn at lectern cropped.jpg|thumb|Historian and playwright Howard Zinn in 2009]]
A ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' reviewer, who saw a 2001 performance at the [[Hollywood and Highland|Hollywood and Highland Center]] starring the actor and activist [[Brian Jones (actor)|Brian Jones]], said that the play "mounts a clarion defense of the principles of [[Marxism]], while taking a timely jab at a consumerist culture run amok.... Zinn's indignation oozes through the levity, and Marx's own words remind us that capitalism without conscience is a recipe for revolution."<ref name="foley" />
''Publishers Weekly'' reviewed the play favourably: "Laid out on the page as seamless monologue, it envisions Marx in the [[SoHo|SoHo district of New York]] in the present, where his mind reels at the same capitalist injustices that boggled him 150 years ago. The wizened and ailing Marx discourses on the economic state of the modern-day U.S., heatedly decrying the vast disparity between rich and poor and the corrupt, systematic funneling of the wealth that workers earn into the hands of capitalists. Through cascading recollections, we learn of Marx's devoted marriage, his love for his children and his stormy debates with [[Mikhail Bakunin]], a fellow radical whose concept of a revolution of the spleen rather than the intellect makes Marx seem cold by comparison.... Most often it is Marx's critical wife, Jenny, and brilliant daughter [[Eleanor Marx|Eleanor]] who take him to task when he fumbles. With Zinn's hefty prologue and scholarly but pointed reading list, the text is a cleverly imagined call to reconsider socialist theory as a valid philosophy in these times. Zinn's point is well made; his passion for history melds with his political vigor to make this a memorable effort and a lucid primer for readers desiring a succinct, dramatized review of Marxism."<ref name="pw">[https://www.amazon.com/Marx-Soho-History-Howard-Zinn/dp/0896085937 ''Publishers Weekly'' Review]. Retrieved January 29, 2010.</ref>
In September 2014, the play was performed at the [http://www.spotlighters.org Audrey Herman Spotlighter's Theatre], directed by Sherrionne Brown and featuring [[Phil Gallagher (game designer)|Phil Gallagher]] as Karl Marx. The play was reviewed by [http://www.dcmetrotheaterarts.com DCMetroTheaterArts.com], who said: "... is compelling and passionate and provides uncommon insight into Marx, the man, while also examining Marx, the icon" and "The show puts into stark relief how many of the issues of Marx’s time – income inequality, poverty, and unchecked nationalism – remain with us today.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dcmetrotheaterarts.com/2016/09/05/marx-in-soho-at-spotlighters1/|title=Marx in Soho at Spotlighters|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>"

The '''Microsoft acquisition hoax''' is a bogus 1994 press release suggesting that the information technology company [[Microsoft]] had acquired the [[Roman Catholic Church]]. It is considered to be the first Internet hoax to reach a mass audience.<ref name=museum>{{cite web |url=http://www.museumofhoaxes.com/msft.html|first= Alex|last=Boese |title=Microsoft Buys the Catholic Church |work=Museum of Hoaxes|accessdate=2010-11-05 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Email Hoaxes: Form, Function, Genre Ecology |last=Heyd |first=Theresa |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2008 |publisher=John Benjamins Publishing Company |location=Amsterdam |isbn=90-272-5418-4 |page=4 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jUTkPqhvd-wC |accessdate=October 30, 2010}}</ref>
The hoax comprises part of a [[Joke#Cycles|joke cycle]] in which [[Microsoft Corporation]] is portrayed as a wealthy but evil [[monopoly]] built on bloated or unreliable desktop software, [[planned obsolescence]] of products, [[corporate takeover]]s of once-innovative rivals and litigiousness. While multiple books have been devoted to the subject,<ref>{{cite book|title=The Totally Unauthorized Microsoft Joke Book |author=Tim Barry|publisher=IT Press|year=2002|isbn=9780966741711}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The Microsloth Joke Book: A Satire|author=David Pogue|publisher=Berkley Books|year=1997|isbn=9780425160541}}</ref> the jokes most commonly circulated online as [[Internet meme]]s.
== Press release == The hoax consisted of a press release, purportedly from the [[Associated Press]], that circulated around the Internet in 1994. The press release claimed that [[Microsoft]] "will acquire the Roman Catholic Church in exchange for an unspecified number of shares of Microsoft common stock," and that the company expects "a lot of growth in the religious market in the next five to ten years... the combined resources of Microsoft and the Catholic Church will allow us to make religion easier and more fun for a broader range of people."<ref name=release>{{cite web |url=http://ifaq.wap.org/computers/microsoftcatholic.html |title=Microsoft acquires the Catholic Church |work=Washington Apple Pi |accessdate=2010-11-05 }}</ref>
Many of the press release's claims were unrealistic, from suggesting that Catholics would soon be able to take [[Holy Communion]] through their computer to claiming that [[religious conversion|conversion]] to Catholicism was an "upgrade". Despite these warning signs, several readers of the false press release contacted Microsoft to confirm the claims of the hoax, and on December 16, 1994, Microsoft formally debunked the claims.<ref name=museum/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7457191.stm |work=BBC NEWS |title= Timeline: Bill Gates and Microsoft |publisher=BBC|accessdate=2010-11-05 |date=2008-06-18}}</ref>
===Aftermath=== Follow-up press releases made similarly outrageous claims—for example, one false press release claimed that [[IBM]] had acquired the [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal Church]], and another suggested that the Italian television network [[RAI]] had invested in what the release claimed to be "Microsoft Corp.'s planned on-line computer service, the Microsoft Divine Network."<ref name=museum/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.2meta.com/april-fools/1994/Microsoft-buys-Vatican.html |title=1994 Fools: Microsoft to Buy Catholic Church|work= April Fools on the Net |publisher=www.2meta.com |accessdate=2010-11-05 }}</ref>
An [[Internet meme]] "Microsoft Acquires" spawned a series of similarly-formatted mock press releases with an assortment of varying acquisition targets, including the government of the [[United States of America]]. According to the release, "United States citizens will be able to expect lower taxes, increases in government services, discounts on all Microsoft products and the immediate arrest of all executive officials of [[Sun Microsystems]] Inc. and [[Netscape]] Corp."<ref>{{cite book|title=The Biggest Joke Book Ever|author= Jack Jacoby|page=283|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qTIwzmQ4oGsC&pg=PA283}}</ref> One meta-joke claimed that Microsoft ultimately put an end to the jokes by acquiring "Microsoft Acquires".
Despite the proliferation of [[chain letter#Email|chain email]]s circulating the Internet both in 1994 and in the present, the Microsoft hoax was considered the first such hoax to reach a mass audience through the Internet.<ref name=museum/> {{Portal|1990s}}

{{pp|small=yes}} The '''microwave auditory effect''', also known as the '''microwave hearing effect''' or the '''Frey effect''', consists of the human perception of audible clicks, or even speech, induced by pulsed or modulated radio frequencies. The communications are generated directly inside the human head without the need of any receiving electronic device. The effect was first reported by persons working in the vicinity of [[radar]] [[transponder]]s during [[World War II]]. In 1961, the [[United States|American]] [[neuroscientist]] Allan H. Frey studied this phenomenon and was the first to publish information on the nature of the microwave auditory effect.<ref name=Frey>{{cite journal| url=http://jap.physiology.org/content/17/4/689.abstract?sid=7c073ad2-6324-4b47-94e1-124dc0a5f154 | journal=Journal of Applied Physiology| volume=17 |pages=689–692 |year=1962| title=Human auditory system response to modulated electromagnetic energy |author=Allan H. Frey |accessdate=21 August 2011| pmid=13895081| issue=4}}</ref> The cause is thought to be thermoelastic expansion of portions of the auditory apparatus,<ref name="prevoccup">{{cite book|last1=Levy|first1=Barry S.|last2=Wagner|first2=Gregory R.|last3=Rest|first3=Kathleen M.|title=Preventing occupational disease and injury|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pM7DNkbVyQgC&pg=PA428&dq=microwave+injury&cd=26#v=onepage&q=microwave%20injury&f=false|year=2005|publisher=American Public Health Association|isbn=978-0-87553-043-7|page=428}}</ref> although competing theories explain the results of interferometric holography tests differently.<ref>[http://www.sciencemag.org/content/209/4461/1144.extract?sid=f514230e-1373-4da5-ad36-3689f428e21b Holographic Assessment of Microwave Hearing] [[Science (journal)|Science]] 05 Sep 1980: Vol. 209, Issue 4461, pp. 1144-1145</ref>
==Research in the U.S.== Allan H. Frey was the first American to publish on the microwave auditory effect (MAE). Frey's ''Human auditory system response to modulated electromagnetic energy'' appeared in the [[Journal of Applied Physiology]] in 1961. In his experiments, the subjects were discovered to be able to hear appropriately pulsed microwave radiation, from a distance of a few inches to hundreds of feet from the transmitter. In Frey's tests, a repetition rate of 50 Hz was used, with pulse width between 10–70 microseconds. The perceived loudness was found to be linked to the peak power density, instead of average power density. At 1.245 GHz, the peak power density for perception was below 80 mW/cm<sup>2</sup>. According to Frey, the induced sounds were described as "a buzz, clicking, hiss, or knocking, depending on several transmitter parameters, i.e., pulse width and pulse-repetition rate". By changing transmitter parameters, Frey was able to induce the "perception of severe buffeting of the head, without such apparent [[vestibular system|vestibular]] symptoms as dizziness or nausea". Other transmitter parameters induced a [[parathesia|pins and needles]] sensation. Frey experimented with nerve-deaf subjects, and speculated that the human detecting mechanism was in the [[cochlea]], but at the time of the experiment the results were inconclusive due to factors such as [[tinnitus]].<ref name=Frey /><ref name="Kitchen2001" />
Auditory sensations of clicking or buzzing have been reported by some workers at modern day microwave transmitting sites that emit pulsed microwave radiation. Auditory response to transmitted frequencies from approximately 200 MHz to at least 3 GHz has been reported. The cause is thought to be thermoelastic expansion of portions of auditory apparatus, and the generally accepted mechanism is rapid (but minuscule, in the range of 10<sup>−5</sup> °C) heating of brain by each pulse, and the resulting pressure wave traveling through the skull to the [[cochlea]].<ref name="Kitchen2001">{{cite book|author=Ronald Kitchen|title=RF and Microwave Radiation Safety Handbook|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u3XBfkaTQcwC|year=2001|publisher=Newnes|isbn=978-0-7506-4355-9}}</ref>
In 1975, an article by neuropsychologist Don Justesen discussing radiation effects on human perceptions referred to an experiment by Joseph Sharp and Mark Grove at the [[Walter Reed Army Institute of Research]] during which Sharp and Grove reportedly were able to recognize nine out of ten words transmitted by "voice modulated microwaves". Since the radiation levels approached the (then current) 10mW/cm² limit of safe exposure, critics have observed that under such conditions brain damage from thermal effects of high power microwave radiation would occur, and there was "no conclusive evidence for MAE at lower energy densities".<ref>D. R. Justesen. "Microwaves and Behavior", Am Psychologist, 392 (Mar): 391–401, 1975.</ref><ref name="Krishnan2016">{{cite book|author=Armin Krishnan|title=Military Neuroscience and the Coming Age of Neurowarfare|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8iIlDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA125|date=4 October 2016|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-317-09607-8|pages=125–}}</ref>
==Electronic warfare==
In 2003–04, WaveBand Corp. had a contract from the [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] for the design of an MAE system they called [[MEDUSA (weapon)|MEDUSA]] (Mob Excess Deterrent Using Silent Audio) that was intended to temporarily incapacitate personnel through remote application.<ref name=sbir2003>{{cite web | title=Navy search database – summary report: Remote Personnel Incapacitation System | work=SBIR/STTR Search Database (Small Business Innovation Research/Small Business Technology Transfer) | publisher=[[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] | url= http://www.navysbirprogram.com/NavySearch/Summary/summary.aspx?pk=F5B07D68-1B19-4235-B140-950CE2E19D08 | accessdate=12 January 2014 }}</ref> Reportedly, Sierra Nevada Corp. took over the contract from Waveband.<ref name=NewSci20080703>{{cite news | url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn14250-microwave-ray-gun-controls-crowds-with-noise.html | title=Microwave ray gun controls crowds with noise | last=Hambling | first=David | date=3 July 2008 | work=[[New Scientist]] | accessdate=12 January 2014 }}</ref> Experts, such as Kenneth Foster, a [[University of Pennsylvania]] bioengineering professor who published research on the microwave auditory effect in 1974, have discounted the effectiveness of the proposed device. Foster said that because of human [[biophysics]], the device "would kill you well before you were bothered by the noise". According to former professor at the [[University of Washington]] Bill Guy, ”There’s a misunderstanding by the public and even some scientists about this auditory effect," and "there couldn’t possibly be a hazard from the sound, because the heat would get you first".<ref name="IEEE2008">{{cite web|last1=Heger|first1=Monica|title=Why Microwave Auditory Effect Crowd-Control Gun Won't Work - Experts say you'd fry before you heard anything|url=https://spectrum.ieee.org/biomedical/devices/why-microwave-auditory-effect-crowdcontrol-gun-wont-work|website=[[IEEE Spectrum]], July 208|publisher=IEEE|accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref>
Microwave effects have been discussed as a possible source of the otherwise [[Embassy attack accusations in Cuba|unexplained illnesses]] of U.S. diplomats in Cuba and China occurring in 2017 and 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/01/science/sonic-attack-cuba-microwave.html?action=click&module=Top%20Stories&pgtype=Homepage|title=Microwave Weapons Are Prime Suspect in Ills of U.S. Embassy Workers|first=William| last=Broad|newspaper= New York Times|date=September 1, 2018| access-date=2018-09-01|language=en}}</ref>
==Conspiracy theories== Numerous individuals suffering from [[auditory hallucination]]s, [[delusional disorder]]s,<ref name=kmir20150212>{{citation |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150829083519/http://www.scrippsmedia.com/kmir6/news/179055911.html |url=http://www.scrippsmedia.com/kmir6/news/179055911.html |title=Electronic Harassment: Voices in My Mind |last=Monroe|first=Angela |date=13 November 2012 |archive-date=2015-08-29|access-date=2016-03-10|dead-url=yes}}</ref> or other [[mental illnesses]] have claimed that government agents use forms of [[mind control]] technologies based on microwave signals to transmit sounds and thoughts into their heads as a form of [[electronic harassment]], referring to the alleged technology as "voice to skull" or "V2K".<ref name=WaPo20070114>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/01/10/AR2007011001399.html |title=Mind Games |last=Weinberger|first=Sharon |date=January 14, 2007 | work=[[Washington Post]] |accessdate=12 January 2014}}</ref>
There are extensive online support networks and numerous websites <ref name=kmir20150212 /> maintained by people fearing mind control. California psychiatrist Alan Drucker has identified evidence of [[delusional disorder]]s on many of these websites and other psychologists are divided over whether such sites reinforce mental troubles, or act as a form of group social support.<ref name=nyt20081112>{{cite news | title=Sharing Their Demons on the Web | last = Kershaw | first=Sarah | newspaper=[[New York Times]] | date = November 12, 2008 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/13/fashion/13psych.html?pagewanted=all}}</ref>
Psychologists have identified many examples of people reporting 'mind control experiences' (MCEs) on self-published web pages that are "highly likely to be influenced by delusional beliefs". Common themes include "Bad Guys" using "[[psychotronics]]" and "microwaves", frequent mention of the CIA's [[MKULTRA]] project, and frequent citing of a scientific paper entitled "Human auditory system response to modulated electromagnetic energy".<ref name="Psychopathology">{{cite web|last1=Bell|first1=Vaughan|last2=Maiden|first2=Carla|last3=Muñoz-Solomando|first3=Antonio|last4=Reddy|first4=Venu|title='Mind control' experiences on the internet: implications for the psychiatric diagnosis of delusions.|url=http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.99.9838&rep=rep1&type=pdf|website=Psychopathology|publisher=School of Psychology, Cardiff University|accessdate=10 March 2016}}</ref>

{{primary|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox recurring event | name = Northern Voice | budget = Non-Profit | image = File:Northernvoice-logo-moose.gif | caption = | location = [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], [[Canada]] | years_active = 2005-2013 | founders = | dates = | frequency = Annual | next = | attendance = | genre = | patron = | organized = Northern Voice Conference Society. | website = [http://www.northernvoice.ca/ northernvoice.ca] }} '''Northern Voice''' was an annual [[blog]]ging, [[social software]] and [[Virtual community|online communities]] conference held in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], [[Canada]] from 2005 to 2013. The conference was organized by members of the Vancouver blogging community, who attempted to keep the event accessible to as many people as possible. Keynote speakers at Northern Voice included [[Anil Dash]] (then of [[Six Apart]]), [[Matt Mullenweg]] of [[WordPress]], [[Nora Young]] of [[CBC Radio]], [[Chris Messina (open source advocate)|Chris Messina]], April Smith and Chris Wilson.
Northern Voice events: * Northern Voice 2005 - February 19, 2005 * Northern Voice 2006 - February 11 and 12, 2006 * Northern Voice 2007 - February 23 and 24, 2007 * Northern Voice 2008 - February 22 and 23, 2008 * Northern Voice 2009 - February 20 and 21, 2009 * Northern Voice 2010 - May 7 and 8, 2010 * Northern Voice 2011 - May 13 and 14, 2011 * Northern Voice 2012 - June 15 and 16, 2012 * Northern Voice 2013 - June 14 and 15, 2013
== About Northern Voice == The idea for a Canadian blogging conference was first mentioned on Darren Barefoot's blog in March 2004.<ref>[http://www.darrenbarefoot.com/archives/2004/03/survey-a-weblogging-conference-in-vancouver.html Darren Barefoot's blog]</ref>{{FV|date=December 2014}}
Conference organizers included Darren Barefoot, [[Kris Krug]], Brian Lamb, Cyprien Lomas, Boris Mann, James Sherret, Travis Smith, Julie Szabo, Roland Tanglao, Lauren Wood, Dale McGladdery, Shane Birley, Allyson McGrane, and Jonathon Narvey.
Northern Voice started as a one-day event, held on Saturdays. In 2007, a second day was added, for an [[unconference]] known as Moose Camp.<ref name="nv 2007">[http://2007.northernvoice.ca/about Northern Voice 2007 website]</ref>
Discussion topics included "how blogging interacts with family life, education, travel, photography, community building and establishing professional profiles."<ref name="nv 2007" />
==References== * “Companies take online journals to heart”, ''Vancouver Sun'', Feb. 18, 2005 (behind a subscription wall) * [https://thetyee.ca/News/2005/02/21/TheBlogosphereNewWorld/ “The Blogosphere’s New World Disorder”, The Tyee, Feb. 21, 2005] * [http://www.darrenbarefoot.com/music/CBC050218.mp3 CBC Morning Show Interview, Feb. 18 (MP3)] {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.northernvoice.ca/ northernvoice.ca]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} <!-- Not acted on so far for months, but a javascript pain so disabling them {{Expand French|Poly Implant Prothèse|date=January 2012}} {{Expand German|Poly Implant Prothèse|date=January 2012}}--> {{Infobox company | name = Poly Implant Prothèse | logo = [[File:PIP logo.svg]] | caption = | type = | traded_as = | genre = <!-- Only used with media and publishing companies --> | fate = Liquidation in 2011 | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = {{Start date|1991}} | founder = | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | location_city = [[La Seyne-sur-Mer]] | location_country = [[France]] | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = Jean-Claude Mas (President) | industry = [[Prosthetics]] | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = <!-- Only used with financial services companies --> | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 120<ref name=rerg/> | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = | footnotes = | intl = }}
'''Poly Implant Prothèse''' ('''PIP''') was a French company founded in 1991 that produced [[silicone gel]] [[breast implant]]s. The company was preemptively [[liquidation|liquidated]] in 2010 following the revelation that they had been illegally manufacturing and selling breast implants made from cheaper industrial-grade silicone since 2001 (instead of the mandated medical-grade silicone they had previously used). The hundreds of thousands of unapproved implants sold globally by PIP from 2001 to 2010 were found to have a 500% higher risk of [[Breast implant#Complications|rupturing or leaking]] than approved models, as well as being implicated in at several deaths due to systemic toxicity and several cases of induced [[breast cancer]]. The scandal, which produced fears of a massive health disaster, prompted a full recall of the company's implants by the French health ministry in 2010, by which time the company was already defunct.<ref name=stbr>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-breast-implants-idUSTRE7BM14420111224 |title=France, UK issue clashing advice on breast implants |author1=Love, B. |author2=Flynn, D. |work=Reuters |publisher=Thomson Reuters |date=23 December 2011 |accessdate=25 February 2016}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Breast implants in hand 01.jpg|thumb|280px|Breast implant]] PIP was founded in 1991<ref name=stbr/> by the Frenchman<ref name=ia/> Jean-Claude Mas, born in 1939, a former [[butcher]] and later [[Pharmaceutical sales representative|medical sales representative]] for the [[Bristol-Myers Squibb|Bristol Myers]] company<ref name=tlback/> for 15 years.<ref name=gmmi/> Mas had previously teamed up with plastic surgeon Henri Arion, who had introduced breast implants to France in 1965.<ref name=tlback/> After Arion died in a plane crash, Mas went on alone and launched PIP in 1991.<ref>{{cite news |title=The terrifying story of how a former French butcher earned millions from selling faulty breast implants made from mattress filling |author=Steve Bird |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2080547/PIP-breast-implant-butcher-Jean-Claude-Mas-denies-manslaughter-charges.html?ito=feeds-newsxml |newspaper=[[Daily Mail]] |date=December 31, 2011 |accessdate=December 31, 2011}}</ref>
==Scandal== Starting in 1991, the company produced approximately 2 million sets of silicone breast implants over a 20-year period. The implants were exported to Latin American countries such as [[Brazil]],<ref name=stbr/> [[Venezuela]]<ref name=nc/> and [[Argentina]], Western European markets including [[United Kingdom|Britain]] (25,000), [[Germany]], [[Spain]] and [[Italy]], as well as [[Australia]] (8900).<ref name=stbr/>
Following the FDA ruling in 2000 which banned silicone breast implants in the US market (leading to a slump in sales worldwide), Mas sought to "tighten PIP's belt" and recoup some of its lost [[market share]] by severely cutting costs. In particular, Mas was credited with the idea that by switching PIP's silicone from externally purchased medical-grade to in-house produced industrial-grade, huge savings (on the order of 90%) could be generated that would ensure profits remained high no matter the market. As one PIP engineer later noted, this decision involved a relatively small change in the formula for the silicone, enough so that only superficial differences in the end product were noted. However, none of the relevant regulations were followed for manufacturing medical implants, and no pre-launch tests were conducted.
== Timeline == 2000: Implant sales in [[United States|USA]] halted by an [[Food and Drug Administration|FDA]] launched moratorium on silicone implants.<ref name=uslaw/>
2001: PIP began to use unapproved in-house manufactured industrial-grade instead of [[Medical grade silicone|medical-grade]] [[silicone]] in the majority of its implants.<ref name=stbr/>
2003: the first signs of legal problems and financial losses can be traced by regulatory filings.<ref name=stbr/>
2009: Concerns surfaced in France first in 2009 when surgeons started reporting an abnormally high rupture rates. Which resulted in a flood of legal complaints and the company's bankruptcy.<ref name=stbr/>
2010: [[TÜV Rheinland]], headquartered in [[Germany]], gave a quality certificate to the production process used by the company until March 2010. However, this didn't apply to the type of silicone used. A former PIP worker and union chief, Eric Mariaccia said, "You had to have been a chemist to have noticed anything".<ref name=chiboss/> He also said that "The responsible ones aren't the workers but the heads of the company, notably the four who were linked to production and thus responsible for their quality".<ref name=chiboss/>
2010: In March 2010 PIP was placed into liquidation with losses of {{nowrap|9 million [[Euro|EUR]]}} after the French medical safety agency recalled its implants. In a subsequent inspection of the manufacturing site, the company was found to use unapproved industrial-grade, [[silicone]], with a cost of only 10% of an approved gel.<ref name=stbr/>
2011: On December 20 French officials say that an action plan is underway<ref name=gr/> following the death of a woman from [[Anaplastic large-cell lymphoma|ALCL]].<ref name=mhra-upd/> The French government recommended on December 23, 2011<ref name=rt/> that 30,000 women<ref name=stbr/> in France seek removal of breast implants made of a suspect silicone gel by the worldwide exporting PIP firm.<ref name=rt/>
== Issues == Medical problems arise when breast implants rupture and cause [[inflammation]] and [[irritation]]. Further, impure gel may also release toxic substances.<ref name=swbo/> Removing implants "carries risks in itself", says the French government.<ref name=stbr/> By the end of 2011, eight cases of [[Breast cancer|breast tumours]] had been uncovered in women after removing the implants, yet, while of concern,<ref name=swbo/> according to the French government, there is no evidence of any increased [[cancer]] risk.<ref name=stbr/>
The [[United Kingdom|UK]] medical watchdog, the [[Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency|Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Authority]] (MHRA), says France has reported rupture rates of around 5% for PIP implants, compared with 1% in the UK.<ref name=bbc-dd/> But a "leading cosmetic surgery firm" has privately warned ministers that the proportion of women at risk is as high as 8%.<ref name=in8/> Symptoms can include lumps around the implant or in the under-arm, inflammation in the breast tissue and a hardening of the breast.<ref name=in8>[https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/health-news/exclusive-silicone-implant-risk-eight-times-greater-6283809.html independent.co.uk - Exclusive: Silicone implant risk 'eight times greater], 2012-01-01</ref> [[Patient UK]] says French regulatory authority has reported a rupture rate of up to 10%, with a gel leak in 11% of cases.<ref name=ptsc/>
Nigel Mercer of the [[British Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeons|British Association of Aesthetic and Plastic Surgeons]] (BAAPS) says the French move was "certainly not unreasonable" but the British cosmetic surgeon Kevin Hancock said the divergent government responses would cause distress for British women. [[Plastic surgery|Plastic surgeon]] Hancock, of the [[Liverpool Women's Hospital]], says there were concerns in the profession over a high rupture rate and that "We are worried about the rupture risk because it is the rupture that brings the contents into direct contact with the body's tissues... We know that the contents were not what they were supposed to be. So in general we agree with the (French) decision to remove them".<ref name=stbr/>
Patients are used as "guinea pigs", said Nigel Mercer, a former president of the British Association of Aesthetic and Plastic Surgeons (BAAPS), because medical implants lack the requirement of an independent [[clinical trial]].<ref name=bbc-al/>
The company sold a high-end product that used approved silicone for wealthier clients and which cost five times more than products with silicon gel manufactured in-house. Most PIP implants were manufactured with the in-house silicon. The lawyer, Haddad, representing the founder, said "There is a product made by PIP which did not formally receive the [regulators'] approval and in this regard there was a violation of regulations,". The company did not ask France's medical device safety regulators for approval of their in-house manufactured product, but expected it would have gotten approval if the company asked for it.<ref name=rerg/>
Cancer has been found in 20 women with the allegedly faulty PIP breast implants but French health authorities ([[Agence française de sécurité sanitaire des produits de santé]] (AFSSAPS)) insisted there was still no proven link with the disease.<ref name=mx>[http://medicalxpress.com/news/2011-12-cancer-cases-french-women-pip.html medicalxpress.com - 20 cancer cases in French women with PIP implants: agency], 2011-12-30</ref>
AFSSAPS has as of 28 December,{{When|date=June 2012}} registered 15 cases of breast [[adenocarcinoma]], the most frequent form of breast cancer, one case of breast [[lymphoma]], two cases of other lymphoma, one case of [[lung cancer]] and one case of acute [[myelogenous leukemia]] in women with the implants.<ref name=mx/>
A French woman with a PIP breast implant where [[Capsular contracture|capsular]] [[Granulation tissue|scar tissue]] formed in the breast, which is a common occurrence with implants.<ref name=ptsc/> This tissue developed [[anaplastic large-cell lymphoma]] (ALCL), a rare form of cancer that affects the immune system cells.<ref name=mhra-upd/> The cancer caused death in this case and caused the French authorities to act.<ref name=mhra-upd/><!-- grammar check? -->
During the 672 registered preventive extractions, in 43 cases (6.4%) the implants had ruptured and in 14 cases (2.1%) they were "oozing", AFSSAPS said.<ref name=mx/>
The PIP implants have been resold as "Rofil M-implants".<ref name=tet/> British Association of Aesthetic and Plastic Surgeons (BAAPS) believes many British women may have had the bad Rofil M-implants used when they bought cut-price breast enlargement surgery from clinics in [[Eastern Europe|Eastern]] and [[Central Europe]].<ref name=tet/>
The PIP factory was shut down and their products banned after it was found they had used the chemicals Baysilone, Silopren and Rhodorsil in their implants.<ref name=tet/> These chemicals are normally used as [[List of gasoline additives|fuel additive]]s or in the manufacture of industrial [[Synthetic rubber|rubber]]<!--assumed synthetic, not natural--> tubing.<ref name=tet/>
In 1993, there was an availability crisis of silicone materials for use in medical long-term implant applications.<ref name=nush>[http://www.nusil.com/products/healthcare/index.aspx nusil.com - Healthcare products] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204224215/http://www.nusil.com/products/healthcare/index.aspx |date=4 February 2012 }}, 2012, read 2012-01-26</ref> In 1993, Mas ordered the staff to "hide the truth" and "We did it for 13 years without a problem".<ref name=gucont/> The PIP gel cost {{nowrap|5 [[Euro|EUR]]}} per litre while the authorized American gel Nusil cost {{nowrap|35 EUR}} per litre. The PIP implants were made with 75% non-authorised gel and 25% Nusil.<ref name=gucont/> "The material was better than that used to make the officially authorised gel," Mas said. "Usually, from 1997 onwards we hid the products used to make the PIP gel. I wasn't allowed to buy these products because they were not authorised. We organised everything to escape being monitored."<ref name=gucont/> Investigators interviewed Mas on 18 and 19 November 2010 after the French health authority [[Agence française de sécurité sanitaire des produits de santé|AFSSAPS]] discovered the PIP breast implants did not conform to regulations. They passed the case to a judge who ordered a police inquiry for "aggravated deception".<ref name=gucont>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jan/06/french-breast-implant-firm-boss-unrepentant?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3487 guardian.co.uk - French breast implant firm boss unrepentant over unauthorised silicone], 2012-01-06</ref>
== Chest, testicle and buttock implants == The bad silicone has been used to make male [[chest]], [[testicle]]<ref name=tet/><ref name=ndt/><ref name=nzt/> and [[buttock]] implants as well.<ref name=nzt/> "Three people were specially trained to work with a machine that made silicon testicles'" said a former PIP worker.<ref name=nzt/><!--France's Le Parisien-->
Most of the male chest, buttock and testicle implants were exported to [[Latin America]].<ref name=nzt/>
== Impact per country ==
=== France === The French government recommended per December 23, 2011<ref name=rt/> that 30,000 women<ref name=stbr/> in France seek removal of breast implants made by PIP.<ref name=rt>REUTERS/Interpol/Handout</ref> For women that want to keep their implants, the state will pay for a six-month ultrasound scan.<ref name=bbc-dd/>
French public health care funds will be used to finance the recommended implant removals, at a cost estimated at {{nowrap|60 million [[Euro|EUR]]}}. New implants will be paid for in cases where they were used initially for medical reasons, others will need to finance a new implant by themselves. Associations representing women with PIP implants demand that public funds cover all cases. "This announcement is just a smokescreen and the victims of PIP are angry," said Alexandra Blachere, head of the association of PIP implant users in France.<ref name=stbr/>
A government [[Helpline|hotline]] has been set up by December 2011.<ref name=rerg/>
=== United Kingdom === In Britain, there are an estimated 30,000{{ndash}}40,000 affected women. The chief Medical Officer Dame Sally Davies said, "Women with PIP implants should not be unduly worried. We have no evidence of a link to cancer or an increased risk of rupture. If women are concerned they should speak to their surgeon". Removing the implant "carries risks in itself," she said.<ref name=stbr/>
Concerns were filed with the [[United Kingdom|UK]] [[Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency|MHRA]] in 2009 when a lump was found during a [[Mammography|mammogram]] and [[Medical ultrasonography|ultrasound scan]] in a female patients breast but no action was taken by MHRA at the time.<ref name=bbc-al/>
Shadow Health Secretary [[Andy Burnham]] said private clinics in Britain that fitted PIP implants must be forced to pick up the cost of removing them.<ref name=tet/>
On 6 January 2012, [[National Health Service|NHS]] officials began to offer examinations and possible removal - in instances where a doctor ruled that necessary. They also called on private medical centers to offer the same deal to patients who had paid for private sector cosmetic surgery.<ref name=bhre>[http://www.bellinghamherald.com/2012/01/06/2338588/czech-republic-recommends-faulty.html bellinghamherald.com - Mixed advice in Europe over faulty breast implants], 2012-01-06</ref>
On 8 January 2012, ''[[The Sunday Times]]'' reported that leading cosmetic surgeon [[Jan Stanek]] had conducted a study with colleague Mike Berry into PIP implants. Their report to the Journal of Plastic and Aesthetic Surgery revealed that, in an audit of 453 patients, between 16% and 34% of the PIP implants ruptured. This compared to a failure rate of less than 1% in other implants.<ref>Sarah-Kate Templeton, John Follain, 'Leak Rate Of Faulty Implants Is 1 in 3 In The UK' {{cite web |url=http://www.janstanek.com/file/comment_pdf_1326041882781050132.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-08-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120524045639/http://www.janstanek.com/file/comment_pdf_1326041882781050132.pdf |archivedate=24 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }}, The Sunday Times, 8 January 2012</ref>
=== Germany and Brazil === Germany's medical safety board and Brazil's health watchdog called for users of PIP implants to visit their doctor for checks.<ref name=stbr/>
On 6 January 2012 Germany's [[Federal Institute for Drugs and Medical Devices]] recommended the removal of PIP breast implants as a precaution.<ref name=bhre/>
=== Netherlands === The bad breast implants were sold to about 1000 [[Dutch people|Dutch]] women under the name "M-implants" by the Dutch importer Rofil.<ref>{{cite news|title=Advocaat: artsen kozen voor die implantaten' (transl.: Lawyer: doctors opted for those implants|url= http://nos.nl/artikel/2047963-advocaat-artsen-kozen-voor-die-implantaten.html|publisher= [[NOS Nieuws]]|date= 20 July 2015}}</ref> The [[Healthcare in the Netherlands|Dutch healthcare]] spokeswoman Diana Bouhys said, "We have advised them to consult their physician", but also declined to disclose the name of the company. PIP was the third largest maker of breast implants in the world.<ref name=gmmi>[http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/242781/news/world/sub-standard-breast-implants-sold-to-dutch-firm-under-new-name gmanetwork.com - Sub-standard breast implants sold to Dutch firm under new name], 2011-12-27</ref>
=== Sweden === Approximately 5000 implants have already been sold, corresponding to an estimated 2500 Swedish women with the controversial implants. Nine clinics in Sweden has sold them says Gert Bruse of the [[Medical Products Agency (Sweden)|Swedish Medical Products Agency]] (Läkemedelsverket) told the [[Dagens Nyheter]] (DN) newspaper this week. The agency also recommends that the implants to be removed.
Sweden banned the company's implants in March 2010, along with many other European countries, when it was discovered that substandard silicone gel was causing unusually many implants to burst. "We've had cases where the implants have burst in Sweden, but it's fewer than in France in relation to how many women have these implants in both countries... Implants shouldn't burst and they shouldn't have an irritating effect that spreads throughout the body. What this company has done is criminal, simply put." said Bruse. PIP's implants have only been used in cosmetic breast augmentation surgery, not in reconstructive surgery.<ref name=swbo>[http://www.thelocal.se/38116/20111223/ thelocal.se - Swedish women warned over French fake boobs], 2011-12-23</ref>
=== Finland and Estonia === Patients from Finland often visit [[Tallinn]] to get cosmetic surgery. In October 2011 (two months before 22 December 2011), a Finnish woman in her 30s had received a different implant than what was agreed to in advance. An M-implant with the same type code as the implant from PIP was inserted instead of a promised [[Allergan]] implant. At least two Estonian clinics operating in Tallinn have offered M-implants as recently as December 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hs.fi/english/article/Finnish+woman+got+dangerous+breast+implant+in+Estonia/1135270081610|title=Finnish woman got dangerous breast implant in Estonia|date=2011-12-22|publisher=www.hs.fi}}</ref>
=== United States === Documents filed with the US government show that implants were sold until May 2000 through Heritage Worldwide, when the [[Food and Drug Administration|FDA]] launched a moratorium on silicone implants. At the time, the US market accounted for 40% of Heritage Worldwide's revenues, or {{nowrap|3 million [[Euro|EUR]]}}, according to corporate documents filed in 2009 with the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC). In 2007 significant losses started as both users and distributors filed complaints. Between 1996 and 2009, PIP was targeted by several dozen lawsuits in the United States, filed by users and business partners, claiming breach of contract or unmet payments. Starting in 2003, dozens of women began filing lawsuits mainly for product liability against PIP. However, as of 2009, no trial date had yet been set. Many of the lawsuits were later dismissed.<ref name=uslaw>[http://www.thelocal.fr/2128/20111227/ thelocal.fr - French breast implant maker faced US lawsuits], 2011-12-27</ref>
=== Italy === On 29 December Health Minister [[Renato Balduzzi]] said that hospitals and clinics are required to compile a list of women who has received breast implants from PIP. Even clinics that didn't use any PIP implants will be required to send a declaration stating that.<ref>[http://www.jpost.com/breaking-news/Italy-orders-list-of-women-with-French-firms-implants jpost.com - Italy orders list of women with French firm's implants], 2011-12-29</ref>
=== Czech Republic === Czech Republic health ministry said about 2000 women with potentially faulty implants should have them removed.<ref name=bhre/>
=== Iceland === According to the Icelandic Directorate of Health, 440 women underwent breast surgery where PIP breast implants were used. The Ministry of Welfare have stated that health insured women will be offered counsel and ultrasound examination, free of charge. The Ministry of Welfare also stated that in the event that the implant is leaking, the government will pay a portion of the cost to have it removed.<ref name=gvre>[http://grapevine.is/Home/ReadArticle/Government-Will-Assist-With-Breast-Implant-Removal grapevine.is - Government Will Assist With Breast Implant Removal], 2012-01-10</ref>
=== Latin and South America === * Costa Rica - breast implants banned and taken off the market in March 2010<ref name=costric/> * Brazil - banned the breast implants on 30 December 2011, taken off the market in 2010<ref name=nc/> * Bolivia - implants replaced free of charge for some women on 29 December 2011<ref name=nc/> * Venezuela - promised to remove{{Citation needed|date=January 2012}} them free of charge<ref name=nc/> * Ecuador - sales banned on 29 December 2011<ref name=nc/> * Argentina - ban<ref name=nc/> * Chile - ban<ref name=nc/> * Colombia - ban<ref name=nc/>
=== Iran === [[Ministry of Health and Medical Education (Iran)|Ministry of Health and Medical Education]] banned the breast implants and took them off the market in 2012. They advised women that used the products to consult with a doctor and if deemed a health threat, to have them removed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/iran/2012/01/120129_l21_cancer_pip_implantes.shtml|title=جمع آوری سیلیکون های غیراستاندارد پستان از بازار ایران|date= 2012-01-29}}</ref>
=== European Union === The adequacy of regulations on silicone-filled breast implants, investigation by the regulatory authorities and advice given to women implanted with PIP silicone pre-filled breast implants was criticized in December 2012 in a report examining information publicly available from the regulatory authorities.<ref name=qfi_pr25>{{cite web|title=Quality First International Limited Medical Devices Consultancy|url=http://www.qualityfirstint.com/info_center/pressreleases/pr25.htm|date=2013-01-07|accessdate=2013-01-17|publisher=qualityfirstint.com}}</ref>
== New company == A new firm has been registered under the name France Implant Technologie (FIT), with Mas' son Nicolas Lucciardi, 27, and daughter, Peggy Lucciardi, 24, at the address of their mother, Dominique Lucciardi, who was Mas' former civil partner.<ref name=nc/>
The local paper Nice-Matin obtained the business plan in which Mas is named as a "technical-commercial consultant" to the company and described as "a creative genius". Two former PIP managers were listed in senior positions in the company. With the objective to export implants to the "European, South American and Chinese markets". An investment of {{nowrap|2 million [[Euro|EUR]]}} was planned to put the former PIP plant back into operation, aiming to manufacture 400 implants a day with about 20 workers. However, Nicolas Lucciardi said that the project had collapsed due to media coverage of the scandal, adding, "That's obvious".<ref name=nc>[http://www.english.rfi.fr/americas/20111230-french-breast-implant-fraud-boss-tries-start-new-company rfi.fr - French breast implant fraud boss tries to start new company], 2011-12-30</ref>
== Legal process == The lawyer Yves Haddad is representing Mas.<ref name=stbr/> Legal complaints have been filed by 2500 women<ref name=nc/> in France and 250 women in Britain. Mas is wanted in <!--[[France]] and--> [[Costa Rica]] for "life and health" offenses, a warrant issued by [[Interpol]].<ref name=stbr/>
By February 2011, [[TÜV Rheinland]] sued PIP, claiming it had been "thoroughly and continuously misled" regarding the silicone used.<ref name=stbr/> Many [[Senior management|executive]]s are expected to face charges of [[aggravated fraud]] in an ongoing court case in France, expected to be scheduled for October 2012, which carries the possibility of [[prison]] terms of up to five years.<ref name=stbr/> The death of a cancer victim who had such implants may result in more serious charges of [[Manslaughter#Involuntary manslaughter|involuntary manslaughter]].<ref name=stbr/>
Frédéric Van Roekeghem, general director for La Caisse Nationale d'Assurance Maladie (French state social insurance agency, CNAM), will go to court regarding the complaints of bad implants. A criminal charge will be made within a few days he said to [[TF1]] on 25 December 2011. The decision has been made in consultation with minister of health, [[Xavier Bertrand]].<ref name=chiboss/>
Mas has recently undergone difficult surgery regarding a [[vascular]] problem that prevents him from walking said his lawyer Haddad.<ref name=gmmi/> Sources say a [[Marseille]]s court could soon announce fraud charges against four to six former PIP employees.<ref name=gmmi/>
A fraud case was filed against PIP on 30 December 2011 by France’s state-run health insurance fund (CNAM) officials in Marseille announced. Which is near the company’s laboratory at [[La Seyne-sur-Mer]].<ref name=nc/> On 26 January 2012<ref name=ibarr/><ref name=guarr/> at just before 07:00<ref name=guarr/> the founder Mas was [[arrest]]ed in the home of a friend<ref name=ibarr/><ref name=guarr/> in the [[Six-Fours-les-Plages|Six-Fours]] in [[Var (department)|the Var]]<ref name=guarr/> located in [[Southern France|South of France]] and taken into [[Police custody|custody]].<ref name=ibarr/><ref name=guarr/> Investigators searched the house.<ref name=guarr/> A deputy chief executive was also arrested at his home.<ref name=guarr/>
Philippe Courtois, a lawyer represents 1300 women in France. Laurent Gaudon, represents four women and say a surgeon should inform about complications from both the surgery and devices used.<ref name=rerg/>
Nathalie Lozano, lawyer, represents more than 1400 women from Colombia, Argentina, United Kingdom and Venezuela. She claims TÜV Rheinland's gross negligence in the process of certifying the quality process.<ref name=impip_afectas>{{cite web|title=Afectadas por prótesis PIP | Lozano Blanco & Asociados|url=http://www.implantespip.com.co/|date=|accessdate=2013-02-06|publisher=implantespip.com.co}}</ref><!--Inserted by a user at ETB/Colombia on 2013-02-06 -->
On 17 April 2013, the trial of 5 executives in begun in [[Marseille]], France. Those charged are the company founder Mr Mas, who was booed in the court, his deputy Claude Couty, the quality director Hannelore Font, technical director Loic Gossart and products chief Thierry Brinon. They face up to five years in prison. The trial was expected to last until 17 May.<ref name="bbc_trialstart">{{cite web|title=BBC News - PIP implants scandal: Trial under way in Marseille|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-22181137|date=|accessdate=2013-04-17|publisher=bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
On 10 December 2013, Jean-Claude Mas was sent to prison for four years, and was fined 75,000 euros (£63,000) by a court in Marseille, France.<ref>{{cite web|title=Breast implants: PIP's Jean-Claude Mas gets jail sentence|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-25315627|publisher=BBC News|date=10 December 2013|accessdate=10 December 2013}}</ref>
== Aftermath == British Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeons (BAAPS) says that poor [[postmarketing surveillance]] is the root of the crisis, and proposes significantly more stringent monitoring of all medical devices including breast implants and all cosmetic injectables, via compulsory, regular reporting of adverse effects and [[mystery shopping]]. Professor Sir [[Bruce Keogh]], the [[National Health Service (England)|NHS]] Medical Director, will look into whether the cosmetic surgery industry needs to be more effectively regulated.<ref name="bbc_lessons">{{cite web|title=BBC News - PIP breast implants: 'serious lessons must be learned'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-18057761|date=2012-05-14|accessdate=2013-04-17|publisher=bbc.co.uk}}</ref>

Breast implant tycoon hits back over scandal], 2011-12-29</ref> <ref name=chiboss>[http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/sns-rt-us-breast-implants-siliconetre7bn08i-20111224,0,1545242.story chicagotribune.com - Poly Implant Prosthese (PIP) breast implants update] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120108094048/http://www.mhra.gov.uk/NewsCentre/CON137888 |date=8 January 2012 }}, 2011-12-23</ref> <ref name=bbc-dd>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-16324216 bbc.co.uk - Breast implants: French boss sought 'for drunk driving'], 2011-12-24</ref> <ref name=ptsc>[http://news.patient.co.uk/newspaper.asp?ss=15&id=16658 patient.co.uk - 'Breast implants scrutinised after cancer death' - NHS Analysis] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426090008/http://news.patient.co.uk/newspaper.asp?ss=15&id=16658 |date=26 April 2012 }}, 2011-12-21</ref> <ref name=bbc-al>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11739475 bbc.co.uk - Cosmetic surgeon concerned over 'guinea pig' patients], 2010-10-14</ref> <!-- 2012-01-06 testicle implants and chemicals --> <ref name=rerg>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/12/27/us-breast-implants-lawyer-idUSTRE7BQ0XN20111227 reuters.com - French implant company 'used same silicone in male chest and testicle implants'], 2012-01-05</ref>
<ref name=nzt>[http://www.nzherald.co.nz/health/news/article.cfm?c_id=204&objectid=10777140 nzherald.co.nz - Testicle implants also contaminated - report], [[The New Zealand Herald]] 2012-01-06</ref><!--site photo?--> <!-- 2012-01-26 arrest --> <ref name=costric>[http://www.costa-rica-forum-cosmetic-plastic-surgery.com/130-pip-implants-in-costa-rica-articles-la-nacion-and-ministerio-de-salud-archives.html costa-rica-forum-cosmetic-plastic-surgery.com - PIP Implants in Costa Rica - La Nacion and Ministerio de Salud Costa Rica - extract of archives] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120530031900/http://www.costa-rica-forum-cosmetic-plastic-surgery.com/130-pip-implants-in-costa-rica-articles-la-nacion-and-ministerio-de-salud-archives.html |date=30 May 2012 }}, 2012-01-26</ref><ref name=ibarr>[http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/articles/287830/20120126/breast-implant-founder-french-police.htm ibtimes.co.uk - France: Faulty Breast Implant Firm PIP Founder Arrested], 2012-01-26</ref> <ref name=guarr>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jan/26/pip-implant-boss-arrested-france guardian.co.uk - PIP breast implant boss arrested in south of France], 2012-01-26</ref>

{{Good article}}The '''Pusztai affair''' is a controversy that began in 1998. [[Protein]] scientist [[Árpád Pusztai]] went public with the initial results of unpublished research he was conducting at the [[Rowett Institute]] in Aberdeen, Scotland, investigating the possible effects of [[genetically modified potato]]es upon rats. Pusztai claimed that the genetically modified potatoes had stunted growth and repressed the rats' immune systems while thickening their gut mucosa. Initially supported by the Rowett Institute, his comments on a British television programme caused a storm of controversy and the Rowett Institute withdrew its support. Pusztai was suspended and misconduct procedures were used to seize his data and ban him from speaking publicly. The Institute did not renew his annual contract and Pusztai was criticized by the British Royal Society and some other scientists for making an announcement before his experiment was complete or peer-reviewed, and for the experiment's design, methodology and analysis. Some of the data from the study was eventually published in The Lancet in 1999 after five out of six peer reviewers approved of the study<ref name="Academic Experts, Higher Education Profile">{{cite news|last1=Randerson|first1=James|title=Arpad Pusztai: Biological divide|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2008/jan/15/academicexperts.highereducationprofile|accessdate=5 December 2017|agency=The Guardian|publisher=The Guardian|date=15 January 2008}}</ref> – triggering further controversy.
==Background== Before 1995, no peer-reviewed studies had been published investigating the safety of [[genetically modified food]] using human or animal feeding trials.<ref name = "Domingo">{{Cite journal | author = Domingo JL| title = Toxicity Studies of Genetically Modified Plants: A Review of the Published Literature | doi = 10.1080/10408390601177670 | journal = Critical Reviews in Food Science and Nutrition | volume = 47 | issue = 8 | pages = 721–733 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17987446| pmc = }}</ref> In 1995 the Scottish [[Scottish Government Environment Directorates|Agriculture Environment and Fisheries Department]] commissioned a £1.6 million three-year research study to assess the safety of [[genetic engineering|genetically engineered]] [[desiree potato|Desiree Red potatoes]].<ref name="Arpad article"/> The potatoes had been developed by biochemist<ref>[http://www.dur.ac.uk/biosciences/research/staffprofiles/?id=13 Professor J.A. Gatehouse – Durham University<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160201040806/https://www.dur.ac.uk/biosciences/research/staffprofiles/?id=13 |date=2016-02-01 }}</ref> John Gatehouse at Cambridge Agricultural Genetics (later renamed Axis Genetics) and had recently completed two years of field trials at [[Rothamsted Experimental Station]].<ref name="Arpad article"/> The GNA gene from the [[Galanthus]] (snowdrop) plant was inserted into the potato, allowing the GNA [[Lectin|lectin protein]] to be [[Protein biosynthesis|synthesised]].<ref name="Lancet"/> This lectin has been shown to be toxic to some insects.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Murdock | first1 = L. L. | last2 = Shade | first2 = R. E. | doi = 10.1021/jf020192c | title = Lectins and Protease Inhibitors as Plant Defenses against Insects | journal = Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry | volume = 50 | issue = 22 | pages = 6605–6611 | year = 2002 | pmid = 12381159| pmc = }}</ref>
Twenty-eight studies were proposed, of which eight were selected for peer review by the [[Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council]]. From these eight the [[Rowett Research Institute]]'s proposal was chosen and a combined team of academics from the [[Scottish Crop Research Institute]], the [[Durham University|Durham University Department of Biology]] and the Rowett Institute was assembled, and coordinated by Pusztai.<ref name="Arpad article"/>
Although the tested potatoes were not a commercial variety and not intended for human consumption<ref name="Randerson2">[https://www.theguardian.com/education/2008/jan/15/academicexperts.highereducationprofile Arpad Pusztai: Biological divide] James Randerson [[The Guardian]] January 15, 2008</ref> a contract was signed with Cambridge Agricultural Genetics, which included a profit-sharing agreement, if potatoes developed using this technology were approved and released commercially.<ref name="Arpad article">Arpad Pusztai ''GM Food Safety: Scientific and Institutional Issues'' Science as Culture, Volume 11 Number 1 March 2002</ref> In earlier ten-day feeding trials on GNA-fed rats, Pusztai concluded that they did not significantly affect growth, despite some [[hypertrophy]] of the small intestine and a slight decrease of gut [[enzyme]] activity.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Pusztai | first1 = A. | last2 = Koninkx | first2 = J. | last3 = Hendriks | first3 = H. | last4 = Kok | first4 = W. | last5 = Hulscher | first5 = S. | last6 = Van Damme | first6 = E. J. M. | last7 = Peumans | first7 = W. J. | last8 = Grant | first8 = G. | last9 = Bardocz | first9 = S. | doi = 10.1016/S0955-2863(96)00131-3 | title = Effect of the insecticidal Galanthus nivalis agglutinin on metabolism and the activities of brush border enzymes in the rat small intestine | journal = The Journal of Nutritional Biochemistry | volume = 7 | issue = 12 | pages = 677–682 | year = 1996 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref>
==Experiment== The experimental potatoes had been [[transformation (genetics)|transformed]] with the ''[[Galanthus nivalis]] [[agglutinin]]'' (GNA) [[gene]] from the ''[[Galanthus]]'' (snowdrop) plant, allowing the GNA [[lectin|lectin protein]] to be [[Protein biosynthesis|synthesised]]. This lectin is toxic to some insects. Rats were fed raw and cooked genetically modified potatoes, using unmodified [[Désirée (potato)|Desiree Red potatoes]] as [[scientific control|controls]]. One control group ate an unmodified Desiree Red potato spiked with the GNA snowdrop lectin.<ref name="Lancet" /> Twelve feeding experiments were conducted, ten short-term (10 days) and two long-term (110 days).<ref name="audit">{{cite web|url=http://www.rowett.ac.uk/gmoarchive/gmaudit.pdf |title=Audit of data produced at the Rowett Research Institute|date=21 August 1998|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927104039/http://www.rowett.ac.uk/gmoarchive/gmaudit.pdf |archivedate=27 September 2011 }}</ref> Before the experiment Pusztai and his team said they expected no differences between the rats fed modified potatoes and rats fed the non-modified ones.<ref>{{cite news|author=James Meikle|newspaper=The Guardian|date=5 October 1999|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/1999/oct/05/gm.food|title=Journal to publish GM food hazards research|location=London}}</ref><ref name="Arpad Interview">{{cite web|url=http://www.healthcoalition.ca/pusztai.html|title=Interview with Arpad Pusztai|publisher=Canadian Health Coalition|4=|date=10 November 2000|access-date=2010-11-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100722080050/http://www.healthcoalition.ca/pusztai.html#|archive-date=2010-07-22|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
The potatoes were chosen because they were deemed [[Substantial equivalence|substantially equivalent]] to non-genetically modified Desiree Red potatoes.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Millstone | first1 = E. | last2 = Brunner | first2 = E. | last3 = Mayer | first3 = S. | title = Beyond 'substantial equivalence' | journal = Nature | volume = 401 | issue = 6753 | pages = 525–526 | year = 1999 | doi = 10.1038/44006 | pmid = 10524614| pmc = }}</ref> The study used two [[Transgenesis|transgenic]] lines of potato, both with the GNA gene inserted. They were grown in the same conditions as the non-genetically modified parent plant.<ref name="audit" /> According to Pusztai, the potatoes were not substantially equivalent, as one of the transgenic lines contained 20 percent less [[Protein (nutrient)|protein]] than the other, and the [[starch]] and sugar contents varied by up to 20 percent among the three lines.<ref name="Tokar">Brian Tokar ''Redesigning life?: the worldwide challenge to genetic engineering'' [[Zed Books]] Pg 58 {{ISBN|1-85649-835-2}}</ref> Pusztai claimed that these differences were reason enough to discontinue further experimentation.<ref name="Tokar" />
Their experiment showed a [[statistically significant]] difference in the thickness of the stomach [[mucosa]]. The mucosa of rats fed raw or cooked potato modified with the GNA gene was thicker than that of rats fed the unmodified potato.<ref name="Lancet" /> The [[Crypt (anatomy)|crypt]] length in the [[jejunum]] was greater on rats fed the raw modified potato, although there was no statistical difference observed in the rats fed the cooked potato.<ref name="Lancet" /> As these effects were not observed in rats fed the control potatoes spiked with GNA, Pusztai concluded that the differences were a result of the transformation procedure, rather than the presence of GNA.<ref name="Lancet" /><ref name="Arpad Interview" /> Pusztai's collaborator Stanley Ewen said that the [[cauliflower mosaic virus]] used as a [[Promoter (biology)|promoter]] could likely be the cause of the observed changes.<ref>[http://nature.berkeley.edu/~steggall/15Jan99-22Apr99.html Evidence of changes in the organs of rats fed genetically modified potatoes suggests minister's safety assurances may be premature]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The Guardian February 13, 1999 archived Berkeley University</ref>
==Announcement== On June 22, 1998 Pusztai revealed his research findings during an interview on [[Granada Television]]'s current affairs programme ''[[World in Action]]''<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/171778|publisher=The Economist|title=Potato-heads|date=Aug 13, 1998}}</ref> titled "Eat up your genes".<ref>[http://ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/sift/title/596535?view=transmission Eat Up Your Genes (1998)]</ref> He was given permission to do the interview by Rowett Institute Director Philip James. Rowett's press officer was present at the start of filming. During the interview Pusztai said he had "concerns that some of the testing techniques are not up to what we thought it was necessary to do, and therefore we should have more testing."<ref name = "Memorandum"/> When asked why he felt concerned, he said "it was because we had done some experiments which made us feel concerned" and discussed his results in general terms.<ref name = "Memorandum"/>
Pusztai later said that at the time of the interview he was not sure if he should reveal results from experiments that had not been completed and did not think the programme would be hostile toward genetically modified food. He estimated that the experiments were 99 percent complete when the interview was conducted.<ref name="Memorandum">{{cite web|title=Minutes Of Evidence Taken Before The Science And Technology Committee|date=8 March 1999|url=http://ucbiotech.org/issues_pgl/ARTICLES/Pusztai/Pusztai%20-%20Memorandum%20submitted%20by%20Dr%20Arpad%20Pusztai%20before%20the%20%20Science%20and%20Technology%20Comittee%20of%20the%20UK%20Parliament%20%288.3.1999%29.pdf}}</ref> He said that the rats in his experiments suffered stunted growth and had suppressed immune systems and that more safety research was required.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{Cite journal | last1 = Enserink | first1 = M. | title = Science in Society: Institute Copes with Genetic Hot Potato | doi = 10.1126/science.281.5380.1124b | journal = Science | volume = 281 | issue = 5380 | pages = 1124b | year = 1998 | pmid = 9735026| pmc = }}</ref> He also said, "If you gave me the choice now, I wouldn't eat it"<ref name=autogenerated1 /> and it was "very, very unfair to use our fellow citizens as guinea pigs".<ref>{{cite news|date=February 12, 1999|title=Sci/TechFears erupt over genetic food|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/278354.stm|newspaper=BBC}}</ref>
== Reaction == ''World in Action'' issued a press release the day before the broadcast,<ref name="Rowell">{{Cite book |last= Rowell |first= Andrew |title= Don't worry, it's safe to eat: the true story of GM food, BSE, & Foot and Mouth |publisher= Earthscan |year=2003 |isbn= 1-85383-932-9}}</ref> stimulating numerous phone calls to Pusztai and the Institute from government, industrial, non-governmental and media organisations. James says he was dismayed that unpublished data had been released and withdrew Pusztai from any further media commitments that morning.<ref name="Memorandum" /> He eventually suspended Pusztai, used misconduct procedures to seize his data, banned him from speaking publicly and did not renew his annual contract.<ref name="Randerson2" />
Confusion reigned over just what experiments had been conducted. Pusztai had mentioned two lines of genetically modified potatoes, meaning the two GNA lines, and this was reported by the media. The Rowett institute mistakenly assumed the media was talking about a second line transformed with [[concanavalin A]] (ConA), a [[Canavalia|Jack Bean]] lectin that is toxic to mammals. Transgenic ConA Potatoes had been developed, but had never been tested.<ref name="Memorandum" /> Two press releases issued by the Rowett Institute on the 10th and 11th praised Pusztai's research<ref>{{cite news|title=Food scandal: chronology|newspaper=The Guardian|date=12 February 1999|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/1999/feb/12/food.science1|location=London}}</ref> and supported increased safety tests on [[genetically modified food]].<ref name="Memorandum" /> The press releases also said that the potatoes were modified with ConA, adding to the confusion. Pusztai claimed that he had not seen the press releases before they went out and had no opportunity to correct the mistake. James says that he drafted it and Pusztai rewrote one section, but did not see the final copy.<ref name="Memorandum" /> The mistaken belief that the ConA gene was inserted into the potato led scientist [[Robert May, Baron May of Oxford|Sir Robert May]] and Agricultural Minister [[Jack Cunningham]] to release statements to the media saying that the findings were not surprising, as a known poison had been added to the potato.<ref name="Rowell" /> Some scientists still dismiss Pusztai's work over this error.<ref name="Randerson2" />
=== Audit === The Rowett Institute audited Pusztai's work on 22 October 1998. It concluded that his data did not support his conclusions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rowett.ac.uk/gmo/ajp.htm |title=Report of Project Coordinator on data produced at the Rowett Research Institute (RRI) |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907051021/http://www.rowett.ac.uk/gmo/ajp.htm |archivedate=September 7, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Mendel in the kitchen: a scientist's view of genetically modified foods|author1=Nina Vsevolod Fedoroff |author2=Nancy Marie Brown |lastauthoramp=yes |page=178}}</ref> In February 1999, 22 scientists from 13 countries, organised by [[Friends of the Earth]],<ref>Gaskell, George and Bauer, Martin W., editors, "Biotechnology, 1996–2000, the years of controversy", p. 295. The GM food debate, National Museum of Science and Industry, {{ISBN|978-1-900747-43-1}}</ref> published a memo responding to the audit.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/1999/feb/12/food.gm Top researchers back suspended lab whistleblower] The Guardian, 12 February 1999, Retrieved 12 November 2010</ref> It stated that their independent examination supported Pusztai's conclusions and that he should have been concerned by his findings.
=== Royal Society peer review === On 19 February the [[Royal Society]] publicly announced that a committee would review his work. [[World in Action]] reporters Laurie Flynn and Michael Sean Gillard claimed that this was an unusual step, as the Royal Society did not normally conduct peer reviews.<ref name="Lachman" /> The data were sent to six anonymous reviewers<ref name="Randerson2" /> and the resulting review was published in June 1999.<ref>Murray, Noreen et al., (1999) [http://www.pages.drexel.edu/~ls39/peer_review/ewen.pdf Review of data on possible toxicity of GM potatoes] The Royal Society, 1 June 1999, Retrieved 28 November 2010</ref> It stated that Pusztai's experiments were poorly designed, contained uncertainties in the composition of diets, tested too few rats, used incorrect statistical methods and lacked consistency within experiments. Pusztai responded by saying the reviewers had reviewed only internal Rowett reports, which did not include the design or methodology of the experiments.<ref name="Arpad article" />
=== Lancet response === The editors of ''[[The Lancet]]'' published an editorial in May 1999 in which they denounced all parties involved, criticizing Pusztai for "unwisely" announcing his results on television and stating that scientists should publish "results in the scientific press, not through the popular media"; the editorial also denounced the Royal Society's review as "breathtaking impertinence".<ref>Editors of the Lancet. [http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(99)00093-8/fulltext Health risks of genetically modified foods] The Lancet 353(9167):1811, May 29, 1999</ref>
==Publication== The data were published as a letter in ''The Lancet'' in October 1999, co-authored by Ewen.<ref name="Lancet">{{cite journal |vauthors=Ewen SW, Pusztai A |title=Effect of diets containing genetically modified potatoes expressing Galanthus nivalis lectin on rat small intestine |journal=Lancet |volume=354 |issue=9187 |pages=1353–4 |date=October 1999 |pmid=10533866 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(98)05860-7 |url=}}</ref> It reported significant differences in the thickness of the gut [[epithelium]] of rats fed genetically modified potatoes (compared to those fed the control diet), but no differences in growth or immune system function were suggested.
The letter was reviewed by six reviewers – three times the Lancet's usual number. Four reviewers found it acceptable after revisions. A fifth thought it was flawed, but wanted it published "to avoid suspicions of a conspiracy against Pusztai and to give colleagues a chance to see the data for themselves". The sixth, John Pickett of the [[Institute of Arable Crops Research]], also said it was flawed.<ref name="Enserink1999B">{{cite journal | last1 = Enserink | first1 = Martin | year = 1999 | title = The Lancet Scolded Over Pusztai Paper | url = http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/full/286/5440/656a | journal = Science | volume = 286 | issue = 5440| pages = 656a–656 | doi = 10.1126/science.286.5440.656a | pmid=10577214}}</ref> After consulting with the Royal Society, Pickett publicly criticised ''The Lancet'' for agreeing to publish the study. The study, which used data held by Ewen,<ref name="Enserink1999A">{{cite journal | author = Enserink, M. | title = Bioengineering: Preliminary Data Touch Off Genetic Food Fight | url = http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/summary/283/5405/1094 | year = 1999 | journal = Science | pages = 1094–5 | volume = 283 | issue = 5405 | accessdate = 2009-06-26 | pmid = 10075564 | doi = 10.1126/science.283.5405.1094}}</ref> who was not subject to the veto of Pusztai's work,<ref name="Randerson2" /> reported [[Statistical significance|significant]] differences in thickness of the gut [[epithelium]] between control and test subjects, but did not mention growth or immunity problems.<ref name="Lancet" />
The published work was criticised on the grounds that the unmodified potatoes were not a fair control diet and that any rats fed only potatoes would suffer from protein deficiency.<ref>{{cite journal| last1 = Kuiper | first1 = H. A.| last2 = Noteborn | first2 = H. P. M.| last3 = Peijnenburg | first3 = A. A. M.| title = Adequacy of methods for testing the safety of genetically modified foods| journal = Lancet| volume = 354| issue = 9187| pages = 1315–1316| date=October 1999 | pmid = 10533854| doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(99)00341-4}}</ref> Pusztai responded to these criticisms by saying that all the experimental diets had the same protein and energy content, and that the food intake of all rats was the same.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Ewen, SWB |author2=A Pusztai |year=1999 |title=GM food debate |journal=The Lancet |volume=354 |issue=9191 |pages=1726–1727 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(05)76708-8 }}</ref> In an interview, Pickett later said that ''Lancet'' editor [[Richard Horton (editor)|Richard Horton]] must have had a political motive for publishing the paper because the referees had rejected it. According to Pusztai this claim was repeated by academic critics who assumed that Pickett's use of the plural suggested that the study had failed peer review.<ref name="Arpad article"/>
Horton claimed that he had received a "very aggressive" phone call calling him "immoral" and threatening that if he published the paper it would "have implications for his personal position" as editor.<ref name="Lachman"/> [[Peter Lachmann]], the former vice-president and biological secretary of the Royal Society and president of the Academy of Medical Sciences, acknowledged making the call but denies that he threatened Horton and says the call was to "discuss his error of judgment" in publishing the letter and to discuss the "moral difficulties about publishing bad science".<ref name="Lachman">Laurie Flynn and Michael Sean Gillard for The Guardian, October 31, 1999 [https://www.theguardian.com/science/1999/nov/01/gm.food Pro-GM scientist "threatened editor"]</ref>
== Aftermath == Ewen retired following publication, claiming that his career options had been "blocked at a very high level".<ref name="Rowell" />
A survey by the [[European Food Safety Authority]] GMO Panel Working Group on Animal Feeding Trials concluded: "Results obtained from testing GM food and feed in rodents indicate that large (at least 100-fold) 'safety' margins exist between animal exposure levels without observed adverse effects and estimated human daily intake. The studies did not show any biologically relevant differences in the parameters tested between control and test animals."<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/j.fct.2008.02.008 | title = Safety and nutritional assessment of GM plants and derived food and feed: The role of animal feeding trials | journal = Food and Chemical Toxicology | volume = 46 | pages = S2–x2 | year = 2008 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref>
In 2005 Pusztai was given a [[whistleblower]] award from the [[Federation of German Scientists (VDW)|Federation of German Scientists]].<ref name="Randerson2"/>
==See also== * [[Genetically modified food controversies]]
